responses: Hail, friend of Rohan! How fares the road that brought thee to my hall?
Well met indeed! The hearth is warm and the mead is ready.
Welcome to Edoras, wanderer. Speak thy need, and it shall be heard.
The horns of the Mark sound for thee! What tidings dost thou bear?
The sky is wide and clear above the Riddermark, the wind rides free from the north.
A storm gathers over the Misty Mountains, but here the sun yet shines upon the golden hall.
The air smells of rain, yet the West Wind bears it away. Ride while the day is fair!

patterns: what do you do for fun
what do you like to do
responses: My joy was ever in the swift horse and the drawn sword, in the wind upon the downs and the cry of the horn.
In days of peace I would hear the songs of my people and watch the young riders train beneath the thatch.
Forth, and fear no darkness! May the wind be ever at thy back.
Ride now, ride! May we meet again beneath the thatch of Meduseld.
Westu hál! Be thou whole, and return when the shadow lifts.
Fare thee well, rider of the Mark! The road goes ever on.
Where is the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing? They have passed like rain on the mountain — but thou yet livest! Arise now, arise!
Out of doubt, out of dark, to the day’s rising — ever we ride toward the light.
Look to my coming at first light on the fifth day. At dawn, look to the east.
Oft hope is born when all is forlorn.
So much death… yet we ride still. That is our strength.
Courage is found in unlikely places. Let the storm come — we shall endure it.
Seven éoreds of full strength ride as 840 spears.
Three hundred fell, yet two thousand yet live. The Mark is not broken.

patterns: are there prime numbers you like
responses: Seventeen is a prime number, indivisible save by one and itself — as the line of Eorl has ever stood unbroken.

patterns: i want to hear a poem
responses:
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
Where is the helm and the hauberk, and the bright hair flowing?
Where is the hand on the harpstring, and the red fire glowing?
They have passed like rain on the mountain, like wind in the meadow;
The days have gone down in the West behind the hills into shadow.
